text: hello this is chef john from food wishes
comm with chicken french which is kind

we got to prep a few things the first of
which is a seasoned flour alright so
we're going to take some regular
all-purpose flour lots of salt got a
season your flour black pepper and of
course my favorite spice cayenne alright
give that a mix up with your fork set
that aside
and another bowl i have two eggs and a
little splash of milk whisk that up
also known as whisk that up and set that
aside
alright i have a 1-pound bag of chicken
scallopini which is just thinly sliced
chicken breast now because I'm nice to
and talk to my butchers they cut it this
way for me alright if you're in one of
the supermarkets where you know there
isn't a butcher and if you help in the

kid over from the greeting card section
who says chicken scallopini never heard

shop at a place where you can actually

want
so you can use chicken breasts for this
pounded out you can use just whole small
chicken breasts for this or you can do
what I did and get some chicken

to take the chicken and you're going to

thoroughly on both sides and of course
as always I'm using a fork here because
I got to work a camera normally I would
do this with my hands one hand for the
wet stuff one hand for the dry stuff
after it's dredged in the seasoned flour
we're going to dump it into the egg

see if you want to prep these ahead you
can have your chicken floured in the egg
waiting for the saute pan in my case I'm
just going to cook a couple pieces here
to show you so I'm going to take a pan
on medium heat with olive oil and butter
when the butter melts I'm going to take
my chicken out of the egg mixture place
it into the preheated oily buttery pan
and cook on medium heat for
approximately two to three minutes per
side if your
using whole small chicken breasts it's
going to take longer if you pounded
chicken breasts out to make your own
little scallopini pieces it depends on
how thick it is
so you got to kind of play it by ear
okay so a couple minutes per side you
want to keep our heat on medium here we
want it to brown but not dark brown okay
when egg gets too dark it gets really
bitter I want a little bit of bitterness
in this egg batter crust but not too
bitter so just looking like that is
about perfect once that's done I'm going
to remove that to a plate and then we're
going to build this very simple chicken
french sauce that's going to be reheated
in the sauce so don't worry set that
aside I'm going to squeeze some fresh
lemon juice into the pan and then some
wine now I like sherry dry sherry a lot
of people like just regular white wine
both work beautifully the sherry will
give you just a little sweeter flavor
the white wine just a little sharper
flavor so up to you I'm also going to
give it a splash of vegetable stock not
chicken stock now you're thinking why
not well because first of all it's
already chicken so it's going to taste

is a really cool color we're going to
reduce that by half by eye we've done
many of these pan sauces when you think
it's by half turn the heat off throw in

technique we've done that in like I
don't know I'm estimating thirty videos
and then keep moving it until it melts
now you're probably thinking I've heard
that chef you got to keep moving it
until it melts what happens if you don't
well nothing if it's just like a few
seconds see here I'm going to stop
because I need to go get my parsley
which is the last ingredient see nothing

when we say keep it moving till it's all
